reviewText:
Given how frequently new instalments in the Call of Duty and Battlefield series are churned out, there's a risk that the gaming world will soon grow tired of the military shooter. As enjoyable as these titles can be, some are starting to feel the genre is growing stale. Sniper Elite V2 is a game that could potentially set that right, offering a refreshingly tactical take on warfare simulation.

Rebellion Developments has strived to plant players directly in the shoes of a frontline sniper with this third-person shooter. It's all about moving around in the shadows, creating diversions and calculating the perfect shot down to the finest detail. The game will certainly find favour with those who value realism over arcade action, but it's not for everyone.

Sniper Elite V2 is essentially a reimagining of its 2005 predecessor, set within the same time frame, with a different spin on events. The game takes place in a battle-ravaged Berlin in the closing days of World War II, with players controlling a US officer dropped into the city to stop the Russians from poaching the Nazi's top scientists.

The storyline runs only surface-deep, though newsreel-style cut scenes and effective voice acting help capture the Zeitgeist of war-torn Europe. In-game backdrops aren't too shabby either. Those rubble-strewn streets and burnt out buildings look glorious at the higher resolutions, and are functional environments where gameplay is concerned.

Missions see players venture behind enemy lines on their lonesome, with only their wits and arsenal as allies. It starts out stealthy and tense as you creep by enemy patrols in search of a suitable vantage point to pick off your target from. Infiltration is a delicate game, and once your sniper's cover is blown, you're unlikely to last very long.

A submachine gun, a silenced pistol and a trusty sniper rifle are the tools of your trade, although other weapons can be picked up later on. There's also a range of explosives on offer that must be used tactically if you want to get out of war-torn Berlin alive. Trip mines can be affixed to the threshold of a doorway to cover your escape, while proximity mines are useful for booby trapping enemy corpses.

Every step you take and every bullet you fire must be carefully calculated in Sniper Elite V2. If you're not fleeing from the scene of an assassination, you'll either be crouch-walking or crawling along the ground since loud footsteps give away your position. This will certainly make the game a no-go for those who prefer swifter-paced action affairs, but as far as the stealth fans are concerned, it's an authentic experience.

Firing stray shots from cover to create a diversion usually pays dividends, as do shrewd takedowns with a silenced pistol bullet. The idea is to come and go like the wind, never giving away your location.

Infiltration is an integral part of the game, but the assassination set pieces are the meat of the experience. Finding the perfect spot to take aim from is only half the battle. There are a lot of variables to take into account when pulling off the perfect shot, such as distance, wind resistance, and even your rate of exhalation.

Pulling off an effective kill gives rise to an immense feeling of satisfaction, heightened by the bullet-cam depiction of your handiwork, which shows your target's internal organs being ruptured via an x-ray effect.

While these segments show off Sniper Elite V2 at its very best, they also highlight one of its biggest drawbacks. While enemy AI can be lethal if you blow your cover, its movement patterns and behaviour are thoroughly predictable. Picking them off from a safe distance is not unlike shooting fish in a barrel. Even on the higher difficulty settings where guard patrols will come at you in force, their attack strategy is enough to make one of Darth Vader's stormtroopers blush.

The solo campaign offers around 10 hours of gameplay, and can be played co-operatively online to pad it out further. A selection of multiplayer modes provides further mileage, along with some unique twists on the military shooter formula. Overwatch mode is the standout offering, casting one player in the role of a sniper providing support for a ground level companion as they complete a range of objectives.

In closing, Sniper Elite V2 does a lot of things right. The tactical components have been well thought out, despite predictable enemy AI upsetting the balance somewhat. Minor issues aside, headshot enthusiasts and stealth fans will find much to love here.

reviewText:
The game is unlike anything else on the market, it is becoming and will become a cult classic just like I predicted when I reviewed this game a few days after the release (the Nazi Zombie expansion packs attest to that)  There are only three major negatives about this game that I can think of:

1) It is not as immersive and complex as the first game;
2) The enemy AI could be improved, but its not terrible;
3) The game could be harder.

I've been playing this game practically non-stop since it came out.

There are certainly some trade-offs for the negatives. The graphics have been improved over the first game, obviously. The Asura engine is now one of my favorite engines, it shined in Aliens Vs. Predator and it's pretty good here. Except I don't understand why the last AVP game had Directx 11 support and this game doesn't. That is kind of inconsistent on the part of Rebellion. The bullet ballistics are still pretty good although they have been made easier since the first game. After a pretty fast learning curve you will be able to snipe targets away pretty easily. So I do kind of wish that it could be harder to snipe targets, for the better kill satisfaction. The graphics are pretty decent, I just with the anti-aliasing applied to every jaggy out there.

The X-ray slow-mo camera. You can shoot your enemy's gonads off, you can shoot their jaw off, you can destroy their rib cages, their kidneys, their heart, their lungs, their eyes. The skull can also be destroyed in many ways even when the enemy is wearing a helmet. You just never get tired of it. I am frankly surprised that other shooting games haven't attempted this before and it is 2012!

The physics of the game are pretty good. There is plenty of destruction to go around. What I also loved is that if you make your character sit and then start slowly rotating the camera view either left or right, you will actually see your character chance stance by turning the torso and moving the legs. It just FEELS that you are controlling someone. Compare that with Skyrim's third person view. When you do the same thing in that game, your character will just start levitating in air without shuffling legs or changing the body position.

The bullet ballistics are good but can get predictable. If you miss your first shot from afar, you can immediately adjust your aim to shoot either slightly to the left or to the right, depending on where the last bullet hit.

The online co-op campaign, something that is missing in so many games, thanks for not having an emblem for that, gamespot. My buddy and I spent hours carefully going through the 11 NON-RECYCLED AND VARIOUS missions. Not only that, there is a horde mode, or the Kill Tally mode, (only 2 players), with 10 waves and an increasing amount of enemies plus enemy trucks, jeeps, halftracks and tiger tanks (last wave only). There are 3 maps for that, each with plenty of locations to hide and hold your ground. You can plant trip wires, mines, dynamite. You can also self ignite enemy vehicles by shooting their fuel tank. You can also kill two or three enemies at a time with one bullet and even kill them with ricochet when they are hiding. There is also a bombing run mode, where you and your partner attempt to collect auto parts for fixing a vehicle and extracting. It is much harder than Kill Tally. There is also an overwatch mode (3 maps only) wherein you and your partner can either play as a sniper or the attacker conducting the ground assault. Finally, there is team deathmatch, with 2 new additional maps that were just added by Rebellion a couple of days ago.

The story is okaish but damn is it made up, straight out of Inglorious Basterds. You are an American (of course) sniper in Berlin in April 1945 (yeah right), killing Germans and....Russians (with American bullets, ooookay), who is supposed to stop the Russian launch of captured V-2 rockets with poisonous gas on London as a prelude for the Cold War. It's preposterous if you have any respect for history.

There is a lack of stealth in the game. I mean you could do it in about half the missions but it's more fun just shooting ze Germans and ze Russkies. Whenever you decide to go stealth, make sure to snipe targets during a loud sound as to not alert nearby enemies. You can also search your slain enemies for the ammo and supplies. You can also pick them up and hide them. As you progress, you find new weapons that you can later use in multiplayer but there aren't that many of them.

The sound is good. There are distant explosions in the background, there are low and high altitude planes flying. There isn't a single civilian in the entire game though.

The enemies could use some work. They aren't terrible though. They shoot, they take cover, they change positions, they zigzag, they throw grenades, they pick up and treat their fallen comrades. The snipe from afar and CHANGE THEIR SNIPING POSITIONS. The only real thing that I would have liked is for them to stick to their cover for longer times if they are being shot at by the sniper. The slowing down of time is neat, but it makes the game super easy. That technique is meant for the controller, since you can't aim as well with the two sticks.

Finally, this is a great game if you are looking for something fresh. I can only hope that Rebellion adds a map editor. There are just so many scenarios to invent here.  The game is somewhat innovative, fun and pretty solid.

All in all, awesome game. Go ahead and support Rebellion. They have redeemed themselves after AVP.

First time I write a review here, so I might as well write it proper.

As I see it, Sniper Elite falls between a number of chairs. It tries to have it's cake and eat it too, and suffers greatly due to it. It's part stealth, part action and long range focused. Problem is, there is no good way of planning attacks, the gameplay is linear and the sheer number of enemies makes this game in a much poorer condition than it could have been in.

The offset is pretty good. There aren't alot of games that focuses on the role of the sniper/marksman out there, and so far nobody has really suceded in recreating that aspect of combat. The game tries to come off as realistic, having it's balistic model as one of it's most adverticed selling points. And to some extent, the bullet physics are great, exept bullets can't penetrate anything, even a wooden fence can stop these bullets. Only thing it actually does penetrate are foilage and bodyparts... the latter it doess rather well.

The levels of the game does not invite the player to plan their attacks, as I stated earlier. In addition, there is far to much focus on close quarters combat for this to really take the art of sniping seriously. Snipers and marksmen are mainly covert operators, and they are usually only used for high value target and recon, not as the one man army portrayed in this game. The gameplay is repetative, unintuitive and plain booring in the long run, and it's far from as interesting as it could have been.

It does, however, provide some entertainment if you have nothing else to do for 30 minutes, but as a game to sit down and enjoy for an evening, it doesn't serve at all.

Hope that you'll find this review helpful, comments are welcome.

reviewText:
I really wish I could recommend Sniper Elite V2... but I just can't. Which is weird because it's a game I enjoyed playing a lot.

Let's start with the good things. Like many said before me, the sniping mechanics are incredibly well done. Sure, some would argue that you shouldn't have to adjust your scopes for a 100m shot, but the maps are relatively small, so it's kind of necessary to have such a drastic bullet drop in this game. It makes the gameplay more challenging and definitely more fun... and that's just the ballistics. The bullet cam and the X-ray vision are what make this game very unique. I don't think I've ever enjoyed sniping so much before.
BUT
These surprisingly fun sniper-sections of the game aren't worth the 20€ you'd be spending on it. (Thank god I got it for free...) Why, you may ask? Because not only the campaign lasts only like 6 hours at most (played on the highest difficulty, which is the only way I would recommend playing this game), only half of it will be spent sniping like that. Which should be okay since you don't want to get bored, obviously. Variety is important you may say, but sniping is literally the only thing they got right in this game... and after an hour of gameplay, you're gonna wish you could just snipe from your safe vantage point again, instead of attempting to sneak through an army of enemies, then inevitably fail.
You may have guessed by now that this game is supposed to be a stealth-based one. A mixture of sneaking your way through to the objective, then assasinate X and hunt the rest of the enemies nearby. That's how it should work.
Guess what: it doesn't. Most of the time you're given a very linear map which is almost completely impossible to sneak through. There are other times where no matter how good you are, you literally can't be stealthy: as soon as you arrive to a checkpoint, you trigger waves of enemies coming at you, no matter how sneaky you are. Then you're left there alone, against hundreds(!) of commies or Jerries with your trusted sniper rifle... and nothing else, since your SMG is ♥♥♥♥-weak and carries up to 2 magazines at once, and your pistol is either used for stealth play (which is either useless or non-existent most of the time), or you could grab a Colt and attempt to benefit from the power of the .45ACP round and its rate of fire. Good luck with that.
So the game forces you to snipe even in a CQB situation, which is absolutely ridiculous. You better grab your Gewehr 43.
Even when stealth play is given, you'll just find it faster, more effective and more fun to shoot your way through the enemies anyway. The other features of the game (setting up traps for your enemy, using distraction, the controls, storyline, co-op and multiplayer) are either laughably bad or just plain useless.

TL;DR: Fun sniping, bad everything else. Worth it if it's free, not worth it if you have to pay for it.
5/10 for the amazing sniping parts

reviewText:
Equipped with a sniper rifle, your protagonist must traverse through various WW II locales to eliminate high-ranking Nazi officials. The story gets interesting when you find out one of the officials is actually a traitor who has vital information as to what the Nazis are preparing for in their desperate attempt to turn the tides.

This game is the epitome of long-range warfare! Sniping enemies has never been more fun! The Ghost Warrior games are nowhere near as exciting as Sniper Elite. The game regularly awards your long-distance, deadly shots with a slow-motion cutscene during which you can see the gory (and glorious) results of your doing. Quite often you get to see how the bones and organs are crushed within the enemies' bodies. Seeing how the heart of an MP40 wielding soldier explodes can be quite disgusting but also quite invigorating!

Unfortunately, while the titular activity in this game is very well carried out everything else in the combat is quite mediocre. Close-combat fight can be quite difficult - it is next to impossible to get a headshot with an MP40 or a Thompson. It is as if the creators deliberately weakened all the other weapons just to force you to use the sniper rifle at all times. Not the mention the amount of bullets you have at your disposal - you will almost never run out of bullets while sniping. I get their point - still, a more refined system could have been put in place.

I heard completing a major part of the game is possible via stealth gameplay - some of the achievements can only be obtained by taking this route. Still, I did not find the insta-kills interesting enough - I had several failed attempts due to the clunky movement of our character. Setting traps is also possible; we have tripmines, landmines and dynamites. Too bad it is quite rarely a must during the roughly 8-hour long campaign.

Those of you who've already read my Nazi Zombie Army reviews must know how much I hate both games. I hate that you have an excellent idea but the execution is just horrible. Connecting to a host took ages and drops from the multiplayer game were frequent. With Sniper Elite V2's campaign I hate them even more as I can now see what levels the creators recycled to get their campaign ready. And now that I've mentioned the DLC titles I can confirm I did not find any cooperative / multiplayer sessions, at all. I expected this, though.

Putting aside the non-existing online gameplay sessions Sniper Elite V2 offers a rather lengthy and great campaign. I do not know what can be more fun than taking out a tank by hitting its fuel tank with a well-aimed shot! This game is THE sniping game. Period!

reviewText:
I had always considered myself a level headed guy.  I've always walked away from a fight, avoided confrontation made sure to keep harsh comments at a low volume so that there was no chance that my intended target might hear me.  I'm not even big hunting, not that I have a problem with it.  I just don't want to see soft bunnies and cute squirrels get obliterated at the twitch of my finger.

Apparantly, once you put a sniper rifle in my hands however, all that peace loving hoo haa goes right out the window.  The window I'm crouched behind as I take a deep breath, hold it, and draw a bead down on your unibrow as viewed through my scope.

Is Sniper Elite V2 a perfect game?  Does it have a riveting story?  Are its graphics amazing?  Nah, not really.  It's a whole hell of a lot of fun though.  The guns feel great, they function great, and you can even notice slight differences in mechanics between the different rifles.  If you're looking for a twitch shooter, this isn't it.  However, if you're not good at twitch shooters?  Don't shy away from this, you get ample time and it's a blast!

If you already have it, you should give it a punt. You should maybe buy it on sale or something. But it's definitely not a full price purchase, as far as I'm concerned.

It tries do to curious stuff, but fails more often than not. There's some nice verticality to the level design at times, and I like how it discourages close quarter combat by making you vulnerable and letting you carry a pitiful amount of submachine gun ammo. There's also a level where you're caught in a crossfire between the Germans and the Russians, having to fend off waves of soldiers from both sides while you slowly claim ground towards your target. It is The Acest Thing.

At times, Sniper Elite is an amazing powertrip. I once had three enemies in close proximity - one patroling, and two standing guard. I took one of the static ones out, masking my shot with the ringing of a church bell. While the patroling soldier was examining the body, I took the other surviving guy out in a similar way. As the sole survivor turned around, he found another dead body, having no clue what was happening. I like to think he was pretty bewildered as a speeding bullet entered his skull.

Ultimately, I spent a lot of time carefully planning a stealthy infiltration, stealthy assasination and stealthy exfiltration that never was. The checkpoints were too far apart to restart every time I was noticed, and I was noticed far more often than I would've liked. The thing is, I feel like it wasn't really my fault most of the time. The conveniently loud artillery fire would misteriously cease indefinitely as soon as I picked off my first target. Enemy reinforcements would magically appear in places I've already sweeped. Cheap stuff like that.

I had fun for a couple of hours, but I came close to giving up on it several times.

reviewText:
A average, maybe even decent game and with the little amount of sniper games available, it might be worth it. But for me, the bad definitely outweighed the good and I often got tired of it or dropped it for a while out of frustration, not at least with the terrible autosave system. If you buy it cheap on sale (personally I got it for free in a short promotion offer on steam), it isn't a waste, but the money could be used so much better and for an older (and short) game it is quite expensive.

The good:

- Quite good sniper mechanics including wind and bullet drop (meaning that you often have to fire a bit over and to the left of the target to hit it, which is realistic).
- Kill cam shows you the bullet penetrating your target in x-ray.
- You can hit grenades in enemy belts and make them explode.
- Graphics are quite good.

The bad:
- The third person looks provide you with a hell of a camera angle, often meaning that you can't see an enemy if he's right in front of you and you are standing close to a wall.
- No real training possibilities meaning you need to practice shooting on the go. This is a problem in a sniper games as it means that you will newer really master how to hit a far away target precisely where you want to, that is, to calibrate the wind and bullet drop. At least not until you are almost finished with the game anyway.
- The autosave is very bad and means some place that you might need to play through half an hour of combat again if you die. Also, to me it seems like some places, the enemies kept coming closer and closer every time I restarted at checkpoint giving me very little time to react and therefore dying a lot of times.
- There is a general lack of genuine good sniping positions. Most positions are of the kind where you would be dead in five minutes in real life. In real life, a good sniping position is NOT sitting behind a small box in the middle of the road, but a place where you can fire without being spotted and then move to another good sniping position before you fire again. This is more or less impossible in this game.
- While stealth is a possibility, most parts of the game more or less enforce you to chose between rambo or rambo-ligth approaches. A real sniper doesn't stand in one position blasting down 15 enemy soldiers firing in on him or assaulting a compound with a submachine gun killing off 50 soldiers.
- There should be a more realistic game mode whit less help for when you want a challenge. In this you should be able to set off your own landmines and trip-mines if you don't pay attention to where you put them and there shouldn't be bullet lines to help you spot where people are shooting at you from.
- The plot is bad and extremely right-wing USA coldwar hawkish. You fight to liberate nazi war criminals as long at they will help the USA build weapons or kill them if they want to do the same for the USSR. You don't assist in winning the war, on the contrary you actually delays the advance of the Red Army thereby prolonging the war and the suffering of both soldiers and civilians in the war zone or living in areas still under nazi control. Actually, you even kills lots of allied soldiers of the red army.
- There are a few bucks in the game, but when they happen, they are major. Like a wagon full of German soldiers not moving at all while I stand right next to it killing them one by one.
- There is no real aiming with other weapons than the sniper riffle, no real use of iron-sight but instead a cross point with a large spread of bullets, even at very close range .... like 1 meter.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite V2 is a third person shooter that takes place during World War 2. The game is less of a run and gun shooter and more on stealth. I never did get into any multiplayer gaming and just played the solo campaign (I am not much for multiplay when the game offers an excellent campaign play through).

I was one of the lucky people to get this game when Steam was offering it for free (for a 24 hour period) so I figured I would try the game out. Why not if its free right?

I was impressed with the use of history and how it made for the story line during my first few minutes of play. I liked how the bullet cam worked as well. Taking aim at a very long shot after controlling your breathing then firing your rifle you will see your bullet travel all the way from your barrel to the target.

What I was most impressed with was the X-Ray kill cam. At certain moments when you have a shot and fire you get an X-Ray of the target and get to see the skeleton and organs get damaged as the bullet travels through. Its pretty gruesome and for my first time seeing this I was amazed at the effects and coolness of it. I wouldn't say its true to life but well done for a video game.

I didn't notice any issues with the game while playing but I did find that it relied on triggered events. For instance, I get in a building and hang back then use my sniper rifle scope to check the area ahead and don't notice anyone around. I fire a shot and nothing, so I creep up to the doorway and then the enemy's spawn.

Setting yourself up to a vantage spot is very useful. In a solo campaign where you camp at a good spot and peg off anyone around is a good tactical move for playing a sniper in any game or any game mode.

You do have other tools at your disposal like trip mines. Setting on up in a door way then heading up to the second floor and getting some kill shots off only to hear the trip wire go off makes me smile. Its an easy kill plus a good method to alert you to move to another spot.

The main campaign story was also good. At the beginning of every mission there was a briefing as to the scenario to play out and what was needed to be done, all of it was voiced.

I played the game with the Xbox 360 controller and Sniper Elite V2 is very friendly for controller support. I can't see myself playing this game with the keyboard and mouse.

I have to admit this game was addicting and I did spend allot of time trying to get the X-Ray kill cam to happen. If it wasn't for that I don't think the game would offer all that much. The bullet cam is cool but its the X-Ray kill cam that really makes the game interesting.

Now I got this game when it was free so I can't really say if its worth the price because when something is free of course its worth the price. However the game is currently $29.99 and although thats not a bad price I would wait till its on sale or the price drops to $9.99. You may also want to wait till the game and the DLC come bundled together for $29.99. Either way the game is fun and worth a play.

reviewText:
Okay, if your favorite slice of the FPS pie is sniping, you might want to give this a go. I got it for free during a 24 hr Steam giveaway, but after having played it through I'd probably pay at least $10 for it. That's not much of a recommendation, but read on if you want to know why I take this particular stance.

It's WW2, and you're a sniper working for American interests at the end of the war. The storyline is okay, not superb, but passable. Well, mostly--the ending is a bit much, but no spoilers here. You are fighting against German and Russian troops while attempting to keep V2 rocket technology from falling into Communist hands. Stock World War II characters and situations are prevalent with no memorable bad guys. I played through the entire solo campaign in less than 24 hours, and while certain battles and moments have stayed with me, a lot of it is fading into one long blur of FPS glory.

The Good:

The sniping can be, at times, truly amazing. The first time you breathe out and squeeze the trigger and watch the slow motion display of the carnage wrought by your well-aimed, well-timed shot, you will feel truly repulsed and rewarded at once. The usual sniping of FPS with either ragdoll physics or the flicking of a light switch effect that seem standard are largely replaced here by visuals that show bullet shattering bone, devastating internal organs, sparking off some metal gear being carried or worn, blowing a large exit wound in the opposite side of your foe, and the realistic tumble of an impacted round. As someone who was trained by the military in forensics and went on to work with one of the largest and most prominent medical examiners in the U.S. (Detroit produces a wealth of experience in forensic and autopsy work), I can say that I was impressed by a lot of what I saw. There are custom settings for different aspects of gameplay, so if one aspect doesn't suit you, you may be able to tinker with it; this includes difficulty of enemies, aiming assistance, and so on. There is a decent amount of variety in the types of objectives, maps, and situations you will encounter, so even though your play through may be somewhat brief, it shouldn't feel too repetitious. When you complete the solo campaign, there are multiplayer, co-op, and challenge modes available to extend replayability as well. What the developers got right, they got very right, and I can easily see myself coming back to this from time to time just to get some target and tactical practice.

The Bad:

The AI is awful. I found myself constructing many elaborate traps only to find I had no way to lure soldiers into them if they were beyond a certain distance. Not in every instance, but in far too many. And once you've set a trap, it's used. No way of retrieving them.You cannot shoot out lights. I find that nearly unforgivable in a game like this. Also, there are bottles set up for target shooting, but apparently they are made of some incredible material because you can't knock over or destroy them from 5 feet away with a handgun. Only sniper rifles can destroy them, which brings unwanted attention of course. Also, the mutant regeneration ability seems out of place, even if it is necessary to the game's mechanics of play. Not saying it is, just saying. And it seems silly, even if satisfying, to be able to destroy all manner of vehicles with a single, well-aimed shot, but not be able to shoot out a lightbulb.

The Ugly:

Multiplayer. Take out the one thing that makes this game worth getting, toss in lackluster maps which, at least in some instances, are clearly imbalanced in favor of one team over the other, and return to everything that is tired and old about WW2 FPS games, and that's the multiplayer I experienced in the three servers I joined. Nothing there to keep me coming back. Oh, and don't forget the players who've memorized the best spots on the best side for each map to absolutely make the play monotonous and frustrating beyond belief. I've played much older games in this genre that did a much better job of it. I have not tried co-op yet (UPDATE: this has changed), and I'm hoping it will offer something more than multiplayer. Oh, and before I go (I edited to add this part), the stealth aspect. It's almost non-existant. There are moments when you can use it, but for a sniping game those moments are far too few. Most of the time you'll feel like Rambo, but with a sniper rifle instead of an M-60. I wish they had made this more of a true stealth game, but alas...

Final Analysis:

Decent fun for the price, if you catch it free or for cheap. If you like sniping, give it a shot. Just don't expect too much out of this title and it'll be alright. If you have a buddy who likes this game, co-op is alright even if somewhat limited and at times redundant. I like it even with its faults.

reviewText:
SPOILERS AHEAD.

Sniper Elite V2 is a rare breed. A WWII game, but with an emphasis on stealth rather than the usual guns blazing tactic seen in other FPS and TPS war games. You play as Karl Fairburne, an American sniper sent into Berlin during the dying throes of WWII to assassinate German rocket scientists.

The main feature of the game, the sniping, is pretty damn good. The bullet cam mechanic is one of the most varied I've seen, unrivalled in realistic shooters, and the only one rivalling it in any shooter maybe being Stranglehold's Precision Aim mechanic. However, on higher difficulty levels, the bullet ballistics and wind mechanics can be fiddly at it's worst, but I find it gives you an amazing high when you can calculate the exact place to shoot, slotting a fresh round from a Gewehr 43 into some Nazi's frontal lobe.

Speaking of which, the guns in this game can be described in one word: beautiful. They stay faithful to the real world counterparts, sharing the names and both the pros and cons, with the Mosin-Nagant's bolt-action reload slowing down your killfest in return for astounding bullet velocity, and the PPSh-41 trading ammo in some places for a higher fire-rate. On lower video qualities, the guns look slightly blocky, but on higher, they look just like the real variants.

-- SPOILERS START HERE --

The story, although contrived at times, is a nice backdrop to your bloodlust. As Karl Fairburne, you are tasked with eliminating multiple German rocket scientists, although there are many ways the game surprises you with this, including attempting to save one as he defects to the American side. It is revealled that as a last ditch attempt to win the war for the Axis, the Germans and the Russians are planning to use V2 rockets aimed at London and filled with deadly Tabun gas. Eventually you shut down the V2 launch site and assassinate the mastermind.

If this sounds all a bit gung-ho, that's because it is. Although Sniper Elite V2 is a great stealth game, deep down inside, it wants to be like Battlefield, it wants to be like CoD, it wants to play with the big boys. The story has been altered from the original Sniper Elite back in 2005, to adjust for the changing times. In the original, you have assistance from the German resistance. This has been taken out of V2, as a large section of FPS fans these days prefer a lone wolf" type story. Some of the in-game areas are a bit too close quarters for what's meant to be a stealthy sniping game

reviewText:
Sniper Elite V2 is a 3rd Person Shooter with the 2nd World War as the setting.

___________________________________________________
++Story++
You are a (correct me if I am wrong) nameless sharpshooter who was sent to Berlin to kill important germans. On your way, you find out that the nazis have a last ace, the V2 Missiles, brutal weapons of mass destruction that are aimed at London, and you make it to your mission to destroy the V2s and defeat the Nazis.


++Gameplay++
The game has the typical shooter corridor as the leveldesign: Take way A, B, or C, but in the end, all ways lead to the same destination. But what is different? You can sneak completely unseen past the enemies, or kill them all with your sniper rifle. Loud noises can drown the noise of your rifle, so you can shoot without warning the enemy. If you just shoot the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything, you will alert the enemy and get quickly killed, which is positive because snipers are not supposed to take a lot of damage. You have some tools like mines and grenades to prevent soldiers from following you or flanking you. If you take out an enemy with the sniper rifle, you will most likely trigger a bullet cam that shows precisely how your bullet penetrates the body of your target, which can look disgusting at times because you see in X-Ray how the bones and organs get damaged (looks very amazing when you shoot your enemy's eye).


++Grafics++
The grafics are the usual standart for shooters back in 2012. Not amazingly good, but not bad either. The faces have
animations, the bullet cam looks great.

++Music++
The music gets annoying fast and is brutally loud, so turn it a little bit down before you start playing. Better play with some own music.


++Features++
Your sniper bullets are actually influenced by gravity and wind if you do not play on easy, which is amazing and makes the shooting harder, and requires you to think a little bit when you shoot.

___________________________________________________

I thought that this game is like Sniper Ghost Warrior a hidden CoD clone, but it is a solid 3rd Person shooter with innovation and ideas, and that makes this game worth to be bought. Good work, Rebellion!

I love this game. Its bullet physics, and the visceral impact the game displays to you is all awesome, and probably worth the purchase alone at the right price.  However, instead of presenting you with a lot interesting sharpshooter scenarios, the game tends to put you more into a meat grinder, by throwing wave after wave of enemies at you.  There were a few times during the game where I had to make a complex shot on my target.  Those instances were fun.  But, they only lasted maybe 2 minutes a piece.  The rest of the game revolves around shooting Nazi A, Nazi B, or Nazi C, (or Russian A, Russian B, or Russian C).

It stops being a sniper game, and becomes a standard shooter.  The times where I had to time my shots to coincide with artillery shells exploding were awesome.  There needs to be more intersting things like that.  Or, if they are going to force me into a building to retrieve a document, I would like to have some sort of melee or takedown option because I always favor stealth over guns blazing.  Overall, now that I have thought about it enough while writing this review, the game is kind of cheap.  Which can make the awesome bullet cam seem like a gimmick.

I can see how someone would think the entire game was basically that, and the rest is just cheap window dressing (i.e. great bullet cam... lame story, cheap enemies, meat grinder missions, poor voice overs, repetive music).  I'm a little torn on this game, but I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite V2 is one of those games that's hit-or-miss (pun semi-intended).  I only just got the PC version, but I've had the Xbox 360 version for close to a year now and the only difference I can see is the graphics quality.  In fact, let's start with that, shall we?

The graphics of Sniper Elite V2 are surprisingly excellent.  The game world itself is far from beautiful, but that is to be expected when you're a lone wolf sniper crawling through the rubble of Berlin in the twilight hours of the Second World War.  The amount of detail is extraordinary.  You can see the leathery texture of an SS officer's jacket just as you're about to blow his brains out.  My only concern is, perhaps, optimization.  Could have used a bit more, but nothing too serious.

The storyline is nothing to write home about, but it gets the job done of linking the missions together.

A lot of the time you'll be crawling around in the ruined streets of Berlin, but you do get to see a few other environments.  Each of the levels is quite linear.  To a lot of players, this is what breaks the game, and I can understand that.  However if  you can get past the linearity it is still a very enjoyable experience.

As for the gameplay, well, it's a sniper game.  You get a sniper rifle, a pistol, and an SMG, along with various booby traps.  The star of the show truly is your rifle.  This should be your go-to weapon throughout most of the game.  The sniper mechanics in this game are phenomenal, and highly customizable.  Bad shot?  You can set it so that bullets come right out of CoD and hit where you're aiming.  Just got off of a BF gaming binge?  You can set it so that bullets are effected by gravity.  Really want to challenge yourself?  You can set it so that not only is there bullet drop, but also wind as well.  On top of this, you will always have to watch your heartrate.  If you're running around a lot, your heart rate is going to spike and your scope will sway heavily.  Stay low, move slowly, and take your time and your heart rate will drop and you can focus on the shot or even slow time.

Once you take that shot, it is very likely that you will go into a bullet cam, which will often show an X-ray view of your target as their organs are shredded by your sniper shot.  You can control the frequency of these bullet cams if you're squeamish or just don't like much gore, but I do not believe you can completely turn them off.  It is, however, quite satisfying when you see your round enter through an enemy's skull, exit out the other side, tumble realistically through the air, and proceed to take out his buddy behind him.

That AI themselves are quite varied between the difficulty levels.  Easy AI will have them walking in circles, wondering where the sniper is that just dropped their friend while you proceed to plink away at their ranks.  Hard AI means that one wrong shot will result in your death.  Medium AI is comfortably in between the two.

Finally, the co-op and multiplayer...  I admit that I have not tried to competitive multiplayer yet, but I did take a quick glance at the options and servers.  There are quite a few servers running and the options for a custom match are outrageous.  As for co-op, you can team up with a shooting buddy and take on either a challenge mission or a wave-based survival mode.  I can say that both of these are extremely fun and, in some ways, make up for the singleplayers linearity with open maps that allow you to roost in whatever sniper perch you find suitable.

All-in-all, I'd say that Sniper Elite V2 is not a game that I would pay a full $60 USD for.  At the current price of $30 USD, however, it is a great game, so long as you're interested.  If you're looking for a game that has basic, yet functioning, stealth mechanics, fun cooperative play, and excellent sniping mechanics, then I suggest you pick up Sniper Elite V2.  It's not the end-all-be-all of sniper games, but it's a hell of a lot better than Sniper: Ghost Warrior.  I can tell you that much!

reviewText:
Fresh from completing Sniper Elive V2, I thought I'd give a brief couple of points on the game.

Positives:
+WWII setting.  Differentiates itself from the current 'modern' trend.  Appreciate WWII was the big thing 5-10 years ago.
+Graphics.  Decent graphics, some nice effects like fire and explosions that look good without too much scrutiny.
+Physics.  Completed on Sniper Elite difficulty so got to experience some decent bullet drop balistics etc.  Shots are definitely missable if you're not careful.
+X-Ray Kill Cam.  This just never gets old.  Ever.  There's something immensely satisfying seeing the skeleton of your enemy shatter into little bits.
+Campaign length.  Though it could be completed quicker (I'm sure), I got a good 10+ hours out of the single player.

Negatives:
-A.I.  Far too easy.  The game can effectively be progressed by simply giving your position away, letting the A.I. run around in the open as they try to hit you.  Makes sniping actually a little too easy.
-Opernplatz.  There's a progression bug on this map. I hit it, couldn't get past and ended up shelving the game for 6-12 months.  Thankfully, a fresh download seemed to let me move on when I finally returned.  Very disappointing.
-Story.  Generic America saves the world (well, America saves London in this instance).  Not very exciting and a little too Hollywood.
-Linearity.  Maps can be moved across using various routes but it's essentially a point A to point B fare.  Shame really.
-Kit too situational.  I had mines, trip mines, dynamite, grenades and a rock (no, NOT  Dwayne Johnson) but using them was VERY situational.  Had the game given me better A.I. (i.e. supressing and flanking etc.) then maybe I'd have used a more tactical approach such as trip mining doorways and the like - but the game just doesn't need it.  You can treat it like any other shooter and progress just fine.  A massively missed opportunity.

Overall, I'd definitely say I had fun with Sniper Elite V2 (taking aside Opernplatz) and would recommend it as being 'worth playing'.  Arguably one of the better sniping games in recent years.

Lastly, it's really cheeky of Rebellion to peddle DLC and the next game on the exit screen.  Bad form, folks.

reviewText:
The game has a lot of flaws but is pretty decent nonetheless. They really drive home the point that this is a sniping game by giving you a very small amount of ammo for your tommygun and pistol. It means that 95% or higher of your kills will be by sniping. It makes it frustrating at times because you have to face off against a squad of guys, ten to twenty guys usually, and snipe them all down. It is not hard at all, just that sniping gets old after a while. The bullet cam is one of the cooler ideas that I have ever seen in a game but unless you turn down its frequency in the options then you are going to be seeing it hundreds of times in the game and it gets old real fast. The realism is entirely absent and the game is highly inconsistent. What I mean is that sometimes a bullet through the chest of an enemy will kill him but a lot of times it just does 50% dmg to him and he stands there like nothing happened to him and fires exactly the same as before you shot him. Tanks also have external gas tanks on them that blow the tank up when shot. Gee, if only it were that simple in real war. Enemy snipers also are psychic. They are magically aware of your exact location and pull off pinpoint headshots on you even when you are somewhere that they should have no idea about, even when you have only snuck around a corner into view without making any noise and they are very far away across the map. The AI is also dumb as fk. They stand up out of cover and stand out in the open the entire game, making snipe-killing them a cinch. Snipers are somewhat hidden but when you see where they are they make almost no effort to re-adjust when you fire their way. They just stand and fire in a snipe battle with you until you quickly kill them. Use your tommygun and pistol ammo very, very sparingly, as you get such a small amount and there are usually no places to get any more ammo during a level until the next level starts and you are magically at full ammo again.

I tried the MP briefly and I have to say it was fun. And surprisingly it still has enough of a fan base that you will find games to join. It has all the classic game modes too: dm, tdm, and ctf, and several co-op modes.

The game has more of a arcade feel to it than an actual sniping game but it is still a pretty decent game that is optimized pretty good and runs smoothly. It can be fun for a once-through, but it is only about as good as the average professional review of the game which was between 60 and 70 out of 100.

reviewText:
So, I spent some time with Sniper Elite V2, here. Overall, it's a 6/10, and I will explain why.

Initially, I got this game on the day it was free, so it scores some bonus points for not costing me any dosh. I installed it right away, excited about a WW2 Sniper shooter! I went in expecting levels with a wide variety of paths, ways to complete your goals, and all sorts of neato things like that. However, I was somewhat disappointed. I write this on finishing the campaign on the Sniper Elite, or Hard, Difficulty of the game.

Over a mind numbing 8 or so hours of dying, dying some more, crawling before dying, and dying again, I finally finished. On these 8 hours, I have to say that the campaign is fairly linear in the paths you can take, with only a few special spots you can get up in that give you any real advantage over the super aim of enemy soldiers. There's not many ways to skin the cat either, when it comes to completing goals or shooting targets. There's one set vantage point, or one set way to stop a convoy of vehicles, etc. I will applaud the story, though, for obtaining my interest and keeping it through the duration of the campaign.

On the story, it's somewhat generic, and I won't spoil it in this review. It was enough of a fresh breath, though, compared to the games around it that it stands out.

Mechanics wise, the bullet drop is interesting. Not as punishing or realistic as Red Orchestra 2, but not as rediculously cheesy as a game like COD. The cover system is mediocre, with your body sometimes sticking out enough for enemies to be able to shoot you, and on sniper elite, this will kill you every time. Enemy detection works alright, and the AI is fairly cohesive. I found myself flanked from time to time, and they aren't grenade spammy.

I don't care about graphics, so that doesn't weigh into this score.

The multiplayer is fun with friends, and so is the co-op. Otherwise, don't bother.

Overall, this game is a short, interesting little game about killing Nazis and Reds. Would I buy it? Only on sale. Would I reccommend it to friends? No. 6/10, and I'll probably wind up getting more time in it playing co-op matches and free for alls with friends, and having a grand time of it.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite V2 is a fun sniping orientated 3rd person shooter. In this game you play as a generic American White male with no backstory sent to single handedly take out hundreds of nazis. Bullet ballistics can be tweaked to be affected by wind, gravity, or nothing for a casual experience. The game does allow you to equip a secondary SMG and pistol but close quarters combat is usually not the correct play because you die very easily in this game. Enemy AI is competent enough to try to flank you while a sniper or mg nest pins you down.

The shooting feels and sounds great. Also the by now iconic gore kill cams of the series are of course present and do a good job at breaking up the monotony of the otherwise very basic combat. There's nothing like seeing the same bullet enter the heart of one enemy and exit out te testicles of another. :) The kill cam can be turned off or lessened.

Stealth is by far the most fun and effective way to play this game. However this is where the game's greatest issue surfaces. While the original sniper elite was about open levels where stealth was incredibly encouraged, Sniper Elite V2's levels feel like guided linear corridors in comparison. Stealth is also just not always an option sometimes which is frustrating.

Enemy AI is for the most part decent. However, one annoyance was that if you are detected by one enemy soldier, for some reason literally all other enemies in the vicinity will immediately know your exact location.

The game also has co-op missions/hoard mode which has no one playing it atm and multiplayer which is still active with a very small community. That being said as someone in US WEST, the closest server to me had a ping of over 500.

Overall the base game is great fun but even for the somewhat low base price of 20 USD I say perhaps wait for a sale unless you really love sniping games. I usually take my time with games but for this game the main campaign literally took me only 6 hours to beat on the medium" difficulty.

As for the DLC
date: Neudorf features an open map that shows that the majority of the main game's maps should've been like. Aka decent sized maps where you can choose how to tackle the objective and use stealth. Landwehr is the hardest one by far which 100% requires stealth or you will lose. St. Pierre is extremely mediocre. All the mentioned DLC take about an hour each to beat which honestly isn't enough content for full price. Kill Hitler might seem cool at first... that is until you realize that you are paying 8 USD for a mission that is literally 20 minutes long."

This game is fun at first, but it gets very repetitive by the time you're halfway through.

It would be more accurate to call this a stealth game than a sniper game, though chances are most of the time you'll get discovered and it'll be a straight up shoot-out anyway. The game flies in the face of game logic that bringing a sniper rifle to a firefight means insta-death for you, with it expecting you to use the rifle in close-quarters combat, as the regular machine guns are the useless weapons this time round.

What you're left with is basically a shoot-em-up, going from point A to B, and repeat, plowing through firefights as you go. You might be expecting some sort of sniper simulator, but even in this game you're a super soldier single-handedly winning the war by wading into battlegrounds, walking up to enemies and shooting them no problem. On harder difficulties it instead turns to frustration as you have to restart the entire part several times because of a hidden sniper taking you out when the coast was supposedly clear.

Gameplay repetetive.
Setting we already know.
Killing germans. Been there done that.
But what is it then that makes this game special?

It's the way it does all these things.
so yhea the gameplay is very repetetive. all you do is move from A to B, set up and shoot a couple of nazi's through their head.
But how. The sniping mechanic in this game is as realistic as i've seen so far in a game.
Do it right and they won't know that you are there. ♥♥♥♥ it up and it's game over. You won't be able to take that much hits so stealth is key.
But expect the frequent fire fights. And that is also something to prepare for. Set up some trip wires, or place a mine under a dead soldier.

The sniping mechanic is the point of the game. And that is it strongest point.
It can be customised to with, But if everything is enabled, it will be as real as it gets.
Take the bullet drip into consideration, and be sure that the wind isn't too strong. Even the gun you are using makes a change in how the bullet drops.
But as soon as you pull the trigger the fun happens. Did you hit the target or did you miss?
Always a fun to see when you actually hit your target. Watch as the bullet slowly enters the enemy's brain and launch small bits of skull and brain through the air.

Level wise, It is nothing really spectacular. Mainly it are the common urban World War 2 settings. (in this case mainly Berlin). With sometimes a country side mission here and there. And the missions are pretty linear.
But is that taking away the fun. Not for me.

Weapons.
Not many weapons are featured in the game. Some pretty common World war 2 sniper rifles. (Even some japanese models, Don't ask me why. Since the japanese aren't even mentioned in the game). A couple of common sub machine guns. And some traps.
But in this case it is in fact Less is more. Because even though there aren't that many guns, They all differ quite a lot from each other. Each sniper rifle has it's own pro's and cons. And that is what makes the difference.

DLC, It's not that spectacular. Some maps, some guns.
But one map in particular which i find oddly enjoying. Of course i am reffering to the Kill Hitler DLC.
Nothing feels better than putting a bullet through the head of Hitler himself. Or at least a video game representation of him.

So sniper Elite V2.
It is a nice game. Not the best game ever. But gameplay wise it's something new. Not something we frequently see in this age's third person shooters.
It's a game that is nothing special, but also a lot of special all in once. that is what makes it great.

TL;DR: only get this if free or heavily discounted. I got it free hence my recommendation.

At times this game had me cheering, cringing or cursing.

Cheering:

- It is immensely satisfying when you line up that perfect shot in a set piece and you watch the impact in that x-ray bullet cam.
- The scripted set pieces (i.e. defending the church, the sniper gallery after retrieving the documents from the soviets) are enjoyable.
- Timing your shots with ambient noise to pick off a squad of enemies one by one without alerting the others feels good and is what this game should be about. Which leads me into the cringing:

Cringing:

- The AI. In some points you can rock full-auto on an MP40 or a Thompson and not alert nearby enemies. Other times you can simply be jogging and every man in the city block will suddenly know where you are. Other times I had enemies round a corner and start shooting at the player character where they couldn't possibly know where he was.
- The Weapons. There are only 2 sniper rifles in the vanilla game that are significantly different enough to be worthwhile selecting for a particular setting or mission. There doesn't appear to be any significant differences between the SMGs worth talking about. You'll probably just chose whichever the enemy in the mission will be using just for ammo availability. There is (at least in my opinion) only one pistol worthwhile using- the Welrod - as it is the only silenced weapon available. This leads me onto the cursing component:

Cursing:

- For some reason, a game that is overtly about sniping forces the player by level design into a significant amount of close quarters fighting, particularly within tunnels and buildings. This means that the player is really limited to a single weapon (the silenced pistol) if they want to keep the stealth / infiltrator feel to the game during these sections of the level. I put this game down (about 75% of the way through the storyline) once I realised that I had spent most of the game using only the Welrod due to level design.

Would I spend more than $10 on this game, no. Would I play it for a few hours if I got it for less than $10? Yes. Which I did - hence I recommend but ONLY at a significant sale price.

Onto visuals and general gameplay:

Most custscenes of the campaign are unecessary, and the end of every mission (MINOR SPOILERS) is literally just the main character walking out of the scene. (END SPOILERS)

Gameplay however is pretty addicting and I'd imagine people who enjoy the first few hours of this game would strive to become better. You don't really have many weapon-choices, however, each weapon offers a number of options for a distinct playstyle of the player's choosing; be it stealth or run and gun.

I would recommend this game for the gameplay, but the campaign is on the fine line between simple or barely worked on.

Simple story guides you through a series of missions that test your sniper skills. Sniping is pretty much what this game is all about and it does it well, with the kill xray cam adding to the general experience. It's fun to play if you only have a couple of minutes to get you to a next checkpoint or if you have a cople of hours to actually finish the whole game in one go. Sniper Elite is exactly what it sounds like. You're a sniper. Most of the gameplay is being stealthy, tactical, and more often than not you're sniping.

The story in this game sucks major ♥♥♥. It's so unoriginal, there's ZERO creativity here at all. Not even the protagonist is all that great, he's dull and he really only talks during cut-scenes and before missions. He doesn't really have a character of his own, he's as thin as a piece of paper. He only acts as the person you control, and nothing more. You probably will not remember him or the game's story for that matter. The pacing is weird and the levels take you from one place to another, and I was left confused as to why he was where he was and how he gets there.

What makes this game so badass though is the gameplay. The controls feel nice and the stealth aspect and tactics are what really make this game stand out. If you get caught, you're gonna die. Even on normal difficulty you die pretty fast. There's regenerating health but the AI is smart enough to shoot at you if they see your head peaking out over a piece of cover, so at first you will die a lot. The checkpoint system can at times be atrocious but for the most part its good.

Keep in mind though that this is NOT a guns blazing shooter. You get 3 guns, one is a sniper rifle (duh),  pistol, and an assault rifle. Most enemies use sniper rifles, and pistol and assault rifle ammunition is very rare and you usually won't even have a full mag on an assault rifle (so use assault rifles only when you need to!) There's an abundance of sniper rifle ammo though but you still want to make your shots count because if you're firing like no tomorrow you will run out of ammo and you CANNOT melee enemies unless they are unaware of you (at least from my experience so far.) The gameplay is fun and surprisingly addicting and is the only reason I'm still playing this game, its just so damn fun and satisfying when you get the slow-motion bullet cam and you get to see the bullet go through your enemy and then it goes into this x-ray vision thing and shows you how the bullet travels inside the enemy's body and everything, it's a really cool and interesting feature.

The cover system is okay, but it's not as fluid as say, Watch Dogs, where you can switch from cover to cover easily. However you can change your stance in this game. You can run (or sprint with Shift), crouch, or go prone. Normal running produces a LOT of sound so you will usually be crouching. I haven't used the prone feature that much because its not particularly useful in most situations since you're usually shooting at people from vantage points with ample amount of cover.

Gunplay is heavily geared towards sniping. Assault rifles and pistols aren't fun to use and you'll really only use your pistol for close range kills because usually you won't have assault rifle ammo and the enemy is too close to use a sniper rifle. You can also lay down traps, these include things like dynamite, wire traps, land mines, and an infinite amount of rocks to throw to distract enemies. Apparently, Karl is an avid rock collector.

Sniper rifles are more complex to use. The scopes are nice, accurate and overall nice looking, and you can even see Karl's BPM and you can slow down time and it even shows you how much bullet drop there will be when aiming at a target, but once you adapt to the bullet drop you won't use this feature as much as you think you would. You cannot use this mode with any other guns except sniper rifles.

The level design accomplishes its goal, its not groundbreaking but the levels do have a good design for the style of gameplay this game is going for (which is medium-long range engagements with enemies and sniping.) You also get a Score during each mission, using the focus mode/bullet time/whatever the hell you want to call it will decrease the amount of points you get. You don't get many points for pistol, assault rifle, or melee kills. You get a lot of points by sniping, particularly getting headshots and from my testing if you get headshots in real time the score you get for that kill will increase versus if you were using the bullet time mode. You also get bonus points if you headshot a moving target or hit them in a vital spot.

Overall, this game's story is a disaster but it's sniper-oriented, stealthy, tactical gameplay is so good and is very addicting. If you love sniping, this game is definitely for you. If you're not a fan of stealth games or sniping though, then the game's name should be more than enough to tell you that this game isn't for you. Oh, and the tutorial level is the most confusing, poorly designed, misleading level ever. If you can get through that nightmare the game gets better from there.

reviewText: Good Game, But It Needs Improvement\nThis is a great game; it captures a lot of depth into how long range bullet ballistics and historical facets of WWII. But it desperately needs to be reworked to fit. There will be many times within the game where you will be forced to think not as a sniper, but a Rambo style killing machine. The beginnings, half-way points, and endings will decently fit the bill as using precision skill and timing with your rifle. As in, scripted parts of the game. But in-between those key points it asks you to do things in another fashion. Such as level's two and three. In 2 you're in many tight corridors, so you have lots of straight shots. But you have zero visibility, enemies running up to you and killing you because you're on the ground, and enemies that will actually spawn before your eyes in the same tunnel. This means that your rifle is practically useless and your best choice is using your machine gun and running. Next we have level 3. Again, lots of tight corridors, low visibility, and more enemies that spawn only when you come within a certain close distance. Your only choice on any difficulty higher than the average is machine guns and running. It's a great game and I love it for its sniping parts, but it needs to be that at least most of the time, not a Call of Duty esc rampage. And I am sorry for using that comparison, but the Duty series appers to be the benchmark that the developers making this went for.

Onto visuals and general gameplay:

Most custscenes of the campaign are unecessary, and the end of every mission (MINOR SPOILERS) is literally just the main character walking out of the scene. (END SPOILERS)

You don't really have many weapon-choices, however, each weapon offers a number of options for a distinct playstyle of the player's choosing; be it stealth or run and gun.

I would recommend this game for the gameplay, but the campaign is on the fine line between simple or barely worked on.

Simple story guides you through a series of missions that test your sniper skills. Sniping is pretty much what this game is all about and it does it well, with the kill xray cam adding to the general experience. It's fun to play if you only have a couple of minutes to get you to a next checkpoint or if you have a cople of hours to actually finish the whole game in one go. reviewText: Good Game, But It Needs Improvement\nThis is a great game; it captures a lot of depth into how long range bullet ballistics and historical facets of WWII. But it desperately needs to be reworked to fit. There will be many times within the game where you will be forced to think not as a sniper, but a Rambo style killing machine. The beginnings, half-way points, and endings will decently fit the bill as using precision skill and timing with your rifle. As in, scripted parts of the game. But in-between those key points it asks you to do things in another fashion. Such as level's two and three. In 2 you're in many tight corridors, so you have lots of straight shots. But you have zero visibility, enemies running up to you and killing you because you're on the ground, and enemies that will actually spawn before your eyes in the same tunnel. This means that your rifle is practically useless and your best choice is using your machine gun and running. Next we have level 3. Again, lots of tight corridors, low visibility, and more enemies that spawn only when you come within a certain close distance. Your only choice on any difficulty higher than the average is machine guns and running. It's a great game and I love it for its sniping parts, but it needs to be that at least most of the time, not a Call of Duty esc rampage. And I am sorry for using that comparison, but the Duty series appers to be the benchmark that the developers making this went for.

This game is exactly what it claims to be: a realistic sniping simulation. The gameplay for the sniping sections in Sniper Elite V2 is very well developed, but for the whole game many more things could have been done. The game is structured like an old-school WWII shooter, divided in missions bound by a plot which is there just to justify the locations and the targets. Once in game, it will look like an arcade-style game made to test or even improve your skills. Speaking of that, there's only one level of difficulty that makes this game enjoyable: Sniper Elite, because ballistics are realistic, and the enemies are tough enough to make the snipers between them very difficult to locate and take down, making the whole experience very funny and satisfying (even though it's terribly hard). Nothing to say about the graphics and audio: great work has been done there.\n\nBuy it only if you're up for a hard challenge, otherwise the plot won't turn up to be complex enough to satisfy you with a three-hours speed run at Easy or even Normal difficulties.
